title: Ron Kind asks GAO to investigate parked trains
text:
Ron Kind asks GAO to investigate parked trains Donovan Slack , Gannett Wisconsin Media Washington bureau 2:38 p.m. CDT October 15, 2015 The La Crosse Democrat wants railroad companies held accountable. Buy Photo U.S. Rep. Ron Kind wants the government to have more power to hold companies like Canadian National Railroad accountable for their operations in local communities. (Photo: Megan McCormick/Gannett Central Wisconsin Media) Buy Photo 
WASHINGTON — Rep. Ron Kind is stepping up his pursuit of accountability for railroad companies that leave trains parked at crossings for hours on end. 
The La Crosse Democrat fired off a letter Thursday asking for an official investigation of the practice by the U.S. Government Accountability Office. 
Such a study could produce proof that parked trains have become a safety risk across the nation and provide the basis for federal officials to take action against railways or for Congress to pass legislation if needed allowing them to crack down. 
“Wisconsin has recently experienced a dramatic rise in rail traffic through our communities, and this has resulted in increased incidences of blocked grade crossings by trains,” Kind wrote in his letter. 
“These prolonged blocked crossings not only present a quality-of-life issue for people in the community due to impediments in the flow of basic traffic and commerce, but when emergency response vehicles are unable to pass, they turn into a serious public safety issue.” Buy Photo 
U.S. Rep. Ron Kind, D-La Crosse, speaks to Stevens Point Journal Media on Monday, Sept. 14, 2015. (Photo: Megan McCormick/Stevens Point Journal Media) 
His quest for greater accountability follows public outrage over the practice in Central Wisconsin, where residents of rural communities such as Junction City and Auburndale regularly find that parked trains block off homes or roads. They are often left sitting during crew shift changes. 
A Gannett Wisconsin Media investigation in August detailed the extent of the problem , including instances when residents resorted to hopping over stopped trains, crawling under them, handing children between rail cars and driving relatives on alternate roads to emergency rooms for fear ambulances would not get around a train in time to provide life-saving treatment. 
Kind has sought help from the Federal Railroad Administration and Canadian National Railway, the dominant railroad in Wisconsin, but so far to no avail. His office said he has not received a reply to a letter he sent the company Sept. 10 asking how the railway plans to reduce the number of road-blockage incidences. 
“It is vital that Canadian National work with our communities and local authorities to reduce the serious public health risks posed by blocking grade crossings for extended periods of time,” he wrote. “I look forward to a timely response from you.” Buy Photo 
Cars stopped on Main Street wait for a train to cross in Junction City on Thursday, Aug. 20, 2015. (Photo: Megan McCormick/Stevens Point Journal Media) 
A spokesman for Canadian National, Patrick Waldron, said CN representatives in Washington have spoken to Kind about the issues since receiving his letter and have had follow up discussions with the congressman’s staff. 
"CN has and continues to meet with local officials in Portage and Wood counties about these issues and has worked to address the concerns about blocked crossings through investments in infrastructure, equipment and train crews," Waldron said. "Those efforts have been successful in reducing the numbers of blocked crossings across the state." 
He added that the company has pledged to kick in $100,000 to help pay for a project that would eliminate crossings from a track section in Auburndale where trains often stop and build roads to redirect vehicle traffic. 
The GAO is an independent, nonpartisan agency that performs investigations, policy analysis and research for Congress in an effort to make government more efficient and effective. 8 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://post.cr/1Lw5kUq TOP VIDEOS
